Where I agree with you:
What you say is very much true in more situations than one would like to 
admit. Large chain stores make sales usually averaging above thirty dollars 
every second. Sales above sixty, all the way to over one hundred happen 
every minute. The chains also make money from tax write offs, some rent 
space to smaller stores/franchises, as well as saving millions due to 
buying in bulk/buying items when the prices are low and sitting on said 
items until the time that the items grow in price. (This works well when it 
comes to seasonal merchandise.) 

It saves more money to not hire loss prevention personnel for every store 
for the above reasons as well as the fact that said people need to have 
certain skill sets of which makes them a rarer employee than say, some 18 
year old kid with a GED that can fill 90% of any available spots within the 
store. (This is just an example of a large sub group of possible employees 
of course.) Since loss prevention requires a skill set in most cases, a 
higher paycheck will result via demand. Here are some other reasons that 
loss prevention can become expensive to a company. Insurance in case of 
property dammage while in persuit, possible sue cases resulting from 
mistaken identity, when chasing the theif, the possible fights that may 
happen because of the incident, and more.
Many loss prevention jobs require the employee to have gone through 
certification courses for self defense, CPR, and to use items such as 
radios, tazers, handcuffs, etc. (Not all jobs require these items, but most 
require at least one.) There are also the prices of uniforms, and then 
there is also the enevitable time when workman's comp. is spent due to 
injury, and/or mental, physical medial conditions caused or exasperated by 
day to day duties.


Loss prevention workers are more at risk for the above than most other 
employees. (Save for the back room store house workers. They oft receive 
injuries from falling heavy merchandise, using lifting machinery, falling 
accidents, and even more problems arising from just off loading merch from 
the trucks that come in every week/day. Having one's foot crushed is not 
fun.

The above are just a portion of the plethora of reasons that I can agree 
with your statement.

Now here's where I find disagreement. (It's pretty short)

While loss prevention personnel can be expensive to have, it's still good 
to hire one or two peoples for the job.
-People to keep an eye on the more expensive merch. (like TVs, computers 
and such) These people generally look out for their own section during the 
day from customers but also are hired to keep the employees from wreaking 
havoc on the bottom line. 

-Black Friday. Large stores do have police in house on holidays like this, 
and for very large sales since customers in many areas are notorious for 
fights, traffic accidents in the parking lot, and for destroying high 
tabbed merchandise. Loss prevention personnel are also hired for this 
because if something else, say a fire or shooting happens, the police would 
leave the store with out choice. LP also backs up the police, stocks items 
to back up the other employees, and over all tend to act as 'grocery 
bouncers'. In some areas Loss prevention employ is a temporary job for the 
holidays. Any kept on after the holiday tend to work the night shift. 

-Loss Prevention personnel on the floor, in sight of every one can be more 
of a deterrant than threat of having the police called. Many new theives, 
and people in general, won't bother trying for something shiney if they 
think the risk is there to get caught, LP employees just being there as a 
physical representation of risk helps in that way. If people knew in 
general that there was no security in a store, and the risk presented was 
just having their face on camera (if they don't know of the blind spots, 
it's worse when they do.) , more often than not the average of loss by 
theft would go up dramatically. Sort of like how a bike lock and chain keep 
honest people honest. 

There's more to it, but overall, it's oft better for the business end of 
things to not hire Loss Prevention Personnel in every store, and just 
cherry pick places to put them where the very few hired would be the most 
effective. It's pretty much situational really. 

Cheers for reading if you got this far. <3

You miss the whole point.

I'm saying from experience as someone who was a caseworker, many of my 
clients faced a number of hurdles to employment. Those who were homeless 
could rarely secure employment no matter how hard they tried. When you 
don't have a number, you get no call back. When you put down a shelter 
number, and someone at the shelter answers and says "Such and Such 
Shelter", most employers will just hang up. I worked for numerous employers 
who have required employees to carry car insurance. I saw first hand 
someone spiral from fulltime employment to homelessness after an emergency 
medical expense. She missed an insurance payment and then got a ticket for 
no insurance. She lost her job for not having the insurance, and then could 
pay the ticket. She went to jail, and then lost her rent house.

This one time as a loss prevention agent. I was working the cameras when I 
saw this guy come in with a stroller with a baby in it. As this guy enters 
the store he says hello to all the associates in the front. Due to prior 
experience of people being overly friendly to associates I decide to watch 
him. So sure enough this guy goes to the alcohol section. Goes through the 
aisle once and doubles back. At this point I was extremely suspicious of 
this character. I knew what was going on but I really hoped I was wrong in 
what I was thinking. Sure enough he selects a few of the top shelf bottles 
and conceals them under the baby stroller and covers them up with a baby 
blanket. At which point he made his way towards the front of the store. I 
break off from the cameras and beat him to the exit. As he exits the store 
I badge him and id myself as loss prevention. This guy immediately runs 
from me leaving the baby with the stroller behind. This guy totally ditched 
his kid and he's yelling out I'm going to call the cops I'm going to call 
the cops" as hes running off. I said call them that'll make two of us. I 
called the police, they get there in about 2 minutes. I explain to them 
what happened. This guy had left his wallet in the stroller. They went to 
his house and grab him. Upon their arrival he claims he was about to call 
the police because someone had kidnapped his child. Of course they knew 
what the real story was and immediately arrested him, I showed the police 
the footage and the guy was arrested for all sorts of things I can't 
remember exactly what but one of the biggest ones was child endangerment. 
The kid was took by Child Protective Services and was later picked up by 
the mother. She later came in and told me that the reason the baby was with 
him was because she finally let him have the baby for a couple days for 
bonding. She previously hadn't trusted the father due to his 
alcoholism.....﻿
